segments.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso himavato pabbatarājassa satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhipeyya.
segments.en: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds on the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yā vā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā, ayaṃ vā himavā pabbatarājā”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—himavā pabbatarājā; appamattikā satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā.
segments.en: “Sir, the Himalayas, the king of mountains, is certainly more. The seven pebbles the size of mustard seeds are tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upenti, upanidhampi na upenti, kalabhāgampi na upenti himavantaṃ pabbatarājānaṃ upanidhāya satta sāsapamattiyo pāsāṇasakkharā upanikkhittā”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the Himalayas, they can’t be reckoned or compared, they’re not even a fraction.”
“In the same way, for a noble disciple …
That’s why you should practice meditation …”

sections.title: “Mendicants, suppose a person was to place seven pebbles…

suttaplex.blurb: As seven bits of gravel are smaller than the Himalayas, so is the suffering remaining to one who has seen the four noble truths.
